subtitles.text: today we're not making spaghetti
carbonara some might say it looks like
carbonara and tastes like carbonara and
has the mouth feel of carbonara the
substances which make up carbonara and
even the personality of carbonara but
this is not carbonara the first thing
we're gonna do is chop up some bacon
that's how you know this isn't carbonara
because if you were making carbonara
you'd be using guanciale you see bacon
comes from a pig whereas guanciale comes
from a completely different animal known
as an italian hog oh my god it looks
like a jumping italian horse you
wouldn't make a hamburger with tiger
meat would you i really hope not tigers
are expensive carbonara is typically
made with egg yolks which is irrelevant
since that's not what we're making don't
accidentally use egg yolks because banjo
music really ruins this dish we'll just
do the classic hold the yolk with your
thumb trick you can also do the back and
forth and whoops maybe no fourth then
make the traditional italian egg white
on toast as an appetizer
this is pecorino romano which you would
use if you're making carbonara which we
are not it gets its name because the
romans who made it had huge pecs so did
the goats they worked out together if
you want to shred your pecorino more
easily you can take a drill put in a
nice big fat screw then you just
okay so
all right if i just maybe okay let's try
no
see in my mind when i thought of this
none of the physics of how objects work
would be an issue if you're italian you
don't need to innovate in this
department because you simply harness
the power of your hand gesture muscles
which makes this a breeze so grate that
into the egg yolk and wang jangle until
you've got cadbury cream egg filling
then we'll add some pepper pepper pepper
and we're good to go and by go i mean
stay because we're not done yet the
original carbonara was made with
hand-crafted artisan spaghetti from the
veneto region each spaghetti crafts
person had their signature style sadly
these days you can only find straight
parallel lined spaghetti and you know it
just really angers me that the craft has
been left to die like nobody cares now
let's just fix that breaking spaghetti
in half is a crime in italy and can land
you in prison for up to nine months it
sounds like an overreaction at first but
the crack sends a shock wave through the
noodle rendering it completely inedible
i mean look here's uncracked spaghetti
and cracked spaghetti if i didn't tell
you that was spaghetti you wouldn't have
even recognized it now we'll salt this
angry water then throw in 156 pieces of
spaghetti keep wang jangling that for
the first bit to keep the spag from
getting clingy by the way spaghetti gets
its name because you put it in the spa
to cook it now our bacon is cooked we're
turning the burner off waiting for this
to cool at least until there's no sizzle
left in a bit longer so we don't
overcook the egg based sauce now i'm
gonna put in a bit of pasta water into
our sauce ingredients to get that cheese
a head start on the melting noodles go
straight from the water into the bacon
pan for a wangjangulation since noodles
are made of wheat this is essentially a
bacon sandwich but if you do strain the
spaghetti make sure to set aside some
pasta water and if you get the kind of
spaghetti with dehydrated meatballs just
pull those out and set them aside then
the sauce can go in and the egg will
cook just enough from the noodle heat
although you can put your pan on low to
thicken it as well because here comes
more pasta water making this nice and
creamy the reason we add pasta water is
so that if you get thirsty while you eat
it you don't have to stop and have a
drink here i'm trying to do that fancy
twist thing but it's not the right tool
and i don't know what i'm doing we'll
finish with some pepper pepper pepper
and some more pecorino or parmesan and
here we don't have carbonara if you want
to really see not carbonara here's an
earlier attempt where i used whole egg
too much heat and for some reason this
came out way worse than my first attempt
with whole egg which came out great so
are the whims of the food gods if this
was carbonara you'd have to be careful
because the carbonistic properties are
so fragile that if you put in a single
pea it would no longer be carbonara it's
a mysterious chemical reaction that only
italian scientists understand
[Music]
should i eat it in the closet oh no
what have i done
i've added peace to a dish that is
otherwise vegetable
free they say it's no game
hang my head as i eat this
shame
[Music]
you

common_steps.title: Introduction
common_steps.text: today we're not making spaghetti carbonara some might say it looks like carbonara and tastes like carbonara and has the mouth feel of carbonara the substances which make up carbonara and even the personality of carbonara but this is not carbonara the first thing
common_steps.explanation: The video starts with an introduction, humorously explaining that the dish being made is not traditional carbonara.

common_steps.title: Prepare the bacon (not guanciale)
common_steps.text: we're gonna do is chop up some bacon that's how you know this isn't carbonara because if you were making carbonara you'd be using guanciale you see bacon comes from a pig whereas guanciale comes from a completely different animal known as an italian hog oh my god it looks like a jumping italian horse you wouldn't make a hamburger with tiger meat would you i really hope not tigers are expensive

common_steps.title: Prepare the egg mixture
common_steps.text: carbonara is typically made with egg yolks which is irrelevant since that's not what we're making don't accidentally use egg yolks because banjo music really ruins this dish we'll just do the classic hold the yolk with your thumb trick you can also do the back and forth and whoops maybe no fourth then make the traditional italian egg white on toast as an appetizer
common_steps.explanation: The host discusses the preparation of eggs, humorously mentioning what not to do, but essentially preparing the egg mixture.

common_steps.title: Grate the cheese

common_steps.explanation: The host grates Pecorino Romano cheese, making jokes about the process.

common_steps.title: Pepper preparation
common_steps.text: and we're good to go and by go i mean stay because we're not done yet
common_steps.explanation: The host mentions pepper, which is part of the preparation for the sauce.

common_steps.title: Boil the spaghetti
common_steps.text: the original carbonara was made with hand-crafted artisan spaghetti from the veneto region each spaghetti crafts person had their signature style sadly these days you can only find straight parallel lined spaghetti and you know it just really angers me that the craft has been left to die like nobody cares now let's just fix that breaking spaghetti in half is a crime in italy and can land you in prison for up to nine months it sounds like an overreaction at first but the crack sends a shock wave through the noodle rendering it completely inedible i mean look here's uncracked spaghetti and cracked spaghetti if i didn't tell you that was spaghetti you wouldn't have even recognized it now we'll salt this angry water then throw in 156 pieces of
common_steps.explanation: The host boils spaghetti while humorously discussing the importance of not breaking it.

common_steps.title: Cook the bacon
common_steps.text: spaghetti keep wang jangling that for the first bit to keep the spag from getting clingy by the way spaghetti gets its name because you put it in the spa to cook it now our bacon is cooked we're turning the burner off waiting for this
common_steps.explanation: The bacon is cooked, which is a humorous substitution for guanciale.

common_steps.title: Combine pasta and bacon
common_steps.text: to cool at least until there's no sizzle left in a bit longer so we don't overcook the egg based sauce now i'm gonna put in a bit of pasta water into our sauce ingredients to get that cheese a head start on the melting noodles go straight from the water into the bacon pan for a wangjangulation since noodles are made of wheat this is essentially a bacon sandwich
common_steps.explanation: The cooked spaghetti is combined with bacon in the pan.

common_steps.title: Add egg mixture to pasta
common_steps.text: but if you do strain the spaghetti make sure to set aside some pasta water and if you get the kind of spaghetti with dehydrated meatballs just pull those out and set them aside then the sauce can go in and the egg will cook just enough from the noodle heat although you can put your pan on low to thicken it as well because here comes more pasta water making this nice and creamy the reason we add pasta water is so that if you get thirsty while you eat it you don't have to stop and have a drink
common_steps.explanation: The egg mixture is added to the pasta and bacon to create a creamy sauce.

common_steps.title: Adjust sauce consistency
common_steps.text: here i'm trying to do that fancy twist thing but it's not the right tool and i don't know what i'm doing we'll finish with some pepper pepper pepper and some more pecorino or parmesan and here we don't have carbonara if you want

common_steps.title: Serve and discuss the dish

problem.goal: To make a dish that resembles spaghetti carbonara but is explicitly not carbonara.

method.procedure: 1. Chop up some bacon instead of using guanciale. 2. Separate the egg yolks from the whites, using only the yolks. 3. Grate pecorino romano cheese and mix it with the egg yolks. 4. Add pepper to the mixture. 5. Cook spaghetti in salted water. 6. Cook the bacon and let it cool. 7. Add pasta water to the egg and cheese mixture to help melt the cheese. 8. Transfer cooked spaghetti directly into the bacon pan. 9. Add the sauce to the spaghetti and bacon, allowing the heat to cook the egg. 10. Add more pasta water to achieve a creamy consistency. 11. Finish with additional pepper and pecorino or parmesan cheese.

result.outcome: The outcome is a creamy pasta dish that visually and texturally resembles spaghetti carbonara, but is explicitly stated to not be carbonara due to its use of bacon instead of guanciale and the humorous approach to the recipe.

problem.subgoal: Introduce the concept of a dish similar to spaghetti carbonara.
problem.context: The video begins with an introduction to a dish that resembles spaghetti carbonara in many ways.

result.outcome: Viewers are introduced to the idea of a dish that is similar to spaghetti carbonara but is explicitly stated not to be carbonara.

problem.subgoal: Chop up some bacon for the recipe.
problem.context: The recipe involves preparing some ingredients, and the current step is to chop bacon.

method.instructions: Chop the bacon into pieces.
method.explanations: Bacon is used in the recipe instead of guanciale, which is traditionally used in carbonara.
method.supplementary: The narration humorously explains the difference between bacon and guanciale, emphasizing that this isn't a traditional carbonara.

result.outcome: The bacon is chopped into pieces, ready to be used in the recipe.

problem.subgoal: Separate egg yolks from egg whites.
problem.context: Preparing ingredients for a dish that traditionally uses egg yolks, but in this case, only egg whites are needed.

method.instructions: Hold the egg yolk with your thumb to separate it from the egg white. Alternatively, use the back-and-forth method to separate the yolk, but be careful to avoid breaking it.
method.explanations: Egg yolks are not needed for this dish, as they would ruin the intended flavor. Instead, only egg whites are used, possibly for a different dish or appetizer.
method.supplementary: Avoid using egg yolks as they would ruin the dish. Banjo music is metaphorically mentioned as something that would ruin the dish, emphasizing not to use yolks.

result.outcome: Egg yolks are successfully separated from the egg whites, which are used for the dish.

problem.subgoal: Grate pecorino romano cheese into the egg yolk.
problem.context: The process involves using pecorino romano cheese, which is typically used for making carbonara, although that is not the current dish being prepared.

method.instructions: Grate pecorino romano cheese into the egg yolk using your hand gesture muscles.
method.explanations: Italians are humorously noted for using their hand gesture muscles, implying that grating cheese can be done easily without innovative tools.
method.supplementary: The narrator humorously suggests using a drill with a screw to grate the cheese but acknowledges it doesn't work as imagined.

result.outcome: Pecorino romano cheese is grated into the egg yolk.

problem.subgoal: Prepare for the next step in the process.
problem.context: Previous steps have been completed, but the overall process is not finished yet.

result.outcome: The current step is completed, but more steps are needed to finish the process.

problem.subgoal: Prepare spaghetti for cooking.
problem.context: The narrator is discussing the traditional way of preparing spaghetti and the importance of not breaking it. They are about to start cooking the spaghetti.

method.instructions: Salt the boiling water before adding the spaghetti. Do not break the spaghetti when adding it to the water.
method.explanations: Breaking spaghetti is considered a crime in Italy and ruins its texture and appearance.
method.supplementary: Breaking spaghetti in half is culturally unacceptable in Italy and can lead to legal consequences.

result.outcome: The spaghetti is added to the salted boiling water without being broken.

problem.subgoal: Prevent spaghetti from sticking together.
problem.context: Cooking spaghetti and bacon on the stove.

method.instructions: Keep stirring the spaghetti frequently while it cooks to prevent it from sticking together. [source]
method.explanations: Stirring the spaghetti helps to prevent it from clumping together by keeping the strands separated. [source]
method.supplementary: The name 'spaghetti' humorously refers to putting it in the 'spa' to cook. [source]

result.outcome: The spaghetti does not stick together and cooks evenly.

problem.subgoal: Combine pasta with sauce ingredients in the pan.
problem.context: Pasta has been cooked and bacon has been prepared in a pan. The cheese and other sauce ingredients are ready.

method.tools: Pan, pasta, bacon, cheese, sauce ingredients
method.instructions: Add a bit of pasta water to the sauce ingredients in the pan to help the cheese melt. Then, transfer the noodles directly from the boiling water into the pan with the bacon and sauce ingredients.
method.explanations: Adding pasta water helps the cheese start melting and creates a cohesive sauce. Transferring noodles directly allows them to absorb the flavors in the pan.
method.supplementary: Ensure the pasta is not overcooked before adding to the pan.

result.outcome: Pasta is combined with bacon and sauce ingredients, starting to form a cohesive dish.

problem.subgoal: Incorporate sauce and reserved pasta water into the spaghetti.
problem.context: After straining the spaghetti and setting aside some pasta water, and removing dehydrated meatballs if present, the sauce is ready to be combined with the pasta.

method.instructions: Add the sauce to the spaghetti and mix. Optionally, place the pan on low heat to thicken the sauce. Gradually add reserved pasta water to achieve a creamy consistency.
method.explanations: Adding pasta water helps create a creamy texture and prevents the dish from being too dry. The heat from the noodles will cook the egg in the sauce slightly.
method.supplementary: Adding pasta water also means you won't need to drink water while eating, as the dish won't be too dry.

result.outcome: The spaghetti is coated in a creamy sauce, with the egg slightly cooked, resulting in a flavorful dish.

problem.subgoal: Finish the pasta dish with pepper and cheese.
problem.context: After adding the egg mixture to the spaghetti and achieving a creamy sauce consistency.

method.instructions: Sprinkle pepper and either pecorino or parmesan cheese over the pasta.

result.outcome: The pasta dish is topped with pepper and cheese, enhancing its flavor.

problem.subgoal: Demonstrate how not to make carbonara.
problem.context: The video is discussing previous attempts at making carbonara, including mistakes made such as using too much heat and whole egg.

method.explanations: Carbonara's properties are delicate, and certain additions can change its nature.
method.supplementary: Adding a single pea would make it no longer carbonara.

result.outcome: An example of a failed carbonara attempt is shown, emphasizing the delicacy of the dish.

problem.subgoal: Remove unwanted ingredients from a dish.

result.outcome: The dish has an unwanted ingredient added to it, causing regret.

common_steps.title: Introduction
common_steps.text: need to understand carbonara does not need cream or peas or ham or whatever else people are putting in it it's so simple today hang out for a second and you're going to learn how to do it right
common_steps.explanation: This segment is an introduction to the video, explaining what carbonara is not and promising to show how to make it correctly.

common_steps.title: Prepare the guanciale

common_steps.explanation: The video explains how to prepare the guanciale (substituted with bacon in this case) by slicing and rendering it in a pan.

common_steps.text: bacon is rendering pasta water is coming up to a boil and we're gonna season our pasta water just a little bit about a tablespoon of salt kosher salt into about four quarts of water usually i'm going to put more salt in because there's so many salty elements in carbonara i want to put less salt in the pasta water so

problem.goal: To make a traditional spaghetti carbonara without cream.

method.procedure: 1. Slice about half a pound of thick-cut bacon into 3/4 inch pieces. 2. Heat a pan to medium and add a tiny bit of olive oil. 3. Add the bacon to the pan and render out the fat until crispy. 4. Season about 4 quarts of boiling water with a tablespoon of kosher salt. 5. Grate 3 ounces each of Pecorino Romano and Parmigiano Reggiano cheese. 6. Whisk together 3 whole eggs and 2 egg yolks. 7. Gradually whisk the grated cheese into the egg mixture. 8. Add fresh ground black pepper to taste. 9. Optionally, temper the egg mixture with a little pasta water. 10. Cook spaghetti in the boiling water until slightly al dente, about 10 minutes. 11. Remove bacon from the pan for garnish and drain most of the fat, leaving about 2 tablespoons. 12. Add the cooked spaghetti to the pan with the bacon fat. 13. Add the egg and cheese mixture to the hot pasta off the heat, stirring to coat without scrambling. 14. If needed, adjust the sauce consistency with reserved pasta water. 15. Plate the pasta and garnish with more cheese and crispy bacon.

result.outcome: The outcome is a creamy, velvety spaghetti carbonara with a rich flavor from the bacon and cheeses, without using any cream. The pasta is coated in a luxurious sauce that is emulsified from the cheese, eggs, and bacon fat, delivering a satisfying and authentic Italian dish.

problem.subgoal: Understand the basic ingredients of carbonara.
problem.context: No specific previous steps necessary. The goal is to learn how to make authentic carbonara.

method.explanations: Carbonara is traditionally made without cream, peas, or ham. It is a simple dish with specific ingredients.

result.outcome: Understanding that carbonara is a simple dish with traditional ingredients, excluding cream, peas, and ham.

problem.subgoal: Prepare and cook bacon for spaghetti carbonara.
problem.context: The goal is to make spaghetti carbonara using bacon as a substitute for guanciale. The cook has decided to use bacon to make the recipe more accessible to an American audience.

method.instructions: Take about a half pound of thick-cut bacon and slice it into pieces about three-quarters of an inch thick. Turn a pan on to medium heat and add a tiny bit of olive oil. Break the bacon into the pan and slowly render out the fat, cooking until crispy.
method.explanations: Thick-cut bacon is used as a substitute for guanciale to make the recipe more accessible. Rendering out the fat makes the bacon crispy, which will be used in the pasta and as a garnish.
method.supplementary: Using a tiny bit of olive oil may not be traditional, but it is added because it feels right when cooking Italian food.

result.outcome: The bacon is sliced, rendered, and cooked until crispy, with its fat ready to be used in the pasta and some pieces reserved for garnish.

problem.subgoal: Season pasta water with salt.
problem.context: Bacon is rendering and pasta water is coming up to a boil.

method.instructions: Add about a tablespoon of kosher salt to about four quarts of boiling water.
method.explanations: The pasta water is seasoned with salt to enhance the flavor of the pasta. However, less salt is used in this recipe because carbonara contains many salty elements.

result.outcome: The pasta water is seasoned and ready for cooking pasta.

problem.subgoal: Prepare finely grated cheese for spaghetti carbonara.
problem.context: The task involves preparing ingredients for making spaghetti carbonara.

method.instructions: Use a cheese grater or the fine setting on a box grater to grate about three ounces each of pecorino romano and parmigiano reggiano cheese.
method.explanations: Pecorino romano is traditionally used in spaghetti carbonara, and parmigiano reggiano is preferred for its quality and flavor. Mixing both cheeses provides a balanced flavor profile.
method.supplementary: Ensure the cheese is labeled 'parmigiano reggiano' and is from Italy for authenticity and quality.

result.outcome: You will have a mixture of finely grated pecorino romano and parmigiano reggiano cheese ready to be used in the spaghetti carbonara recipe.

problem.subgoal: Prepare the egg and cheese mixture for carbonara.
problem.context: The task involves preparing ingredients for making spaghetti carbonara. Finely grated pecorino romano and parmigiano reggiano cheese have been prepared.

method.instructions: Crack three whole eggs and separate two egg yolks into a bowl. Whisk them together. Then, whisk the grated cheese into the egg mixture. Add a generous amount of freshly ground black pepper and whisk it in.
method.explanations: Using both whole eggs and egg yolks provides richness without being overly heavy. The pepper adds flavor to the mixture.
method.supplementary: Adjust the amount of pepper according to personal preference. The narrator refers to the pepper grinder as 'Sergeant Gilbert,' indicating a humorous or personal touch in the cooking process.

result.outcome: You will have a well-mixed egg, cheese, and pepper mixture ready to use in the carbonara recipe.

subgoal_summaries.title: Cook the bacon and boil the spaghetti

problem.subgoal: Prepare bacon and spaghetti for carbonara.
problem.context: The bacon is being cooked and rendered in a pan. Spaghetti is being boiled in water.

method.instructions: Occasionally turn the bacon in the pan to render the fat. Add a little boiling water to the egg mixture to equalize temperatures and loosen it. Drop the spaghetti into the boiling water and let it cook. Turn the heat down on the bacon, and once rendered, take some out for garnish and drain on a paper towel. Turn off the heat and drain off most of the bacon fat, leaving about two tablespoons.
method.explanations: Adding boiling water to the egg mixture helps equalize the temperature and loosens the mixture, making the pasta come together easier. Leaving some bacon fat in the pan adds flavor to the carbonara.
method.supplementary: Be careful not to overcook the bacon. Remember to turn off the heat after draining the bacon fat.

result.outcome: Bacon is rendered and some fat is retained in the pan. Spaghetti is cooking in boiling water. Bacon is ready for garnish.

problem.subgoal: Cook spaghetti to al dente and transfer to a baking pan.
problem.context: The process involves cooking spaghetti, starting with choosing a brand of pasta and boiling it in a pot.

method.instructions: Cook the spaghetti in a pot for about 10 minutes until slightly al dente. Then, use tongs to transfer the spaghetti from the pot to a baking pan.
method.explanations: Cooking the spaghetti to slightly al dente ensures it will finish cooking in the baking pan, allowing it to absorb flavors.
method.supplementary: Leave the cooking water in the pot as it will be used later. The spaghetti generates a lot of heat, which is important for the next steps.

result.outcome: The spaghetti is cooked to slightly al dente and transferred to a baking pan, retaining heat for further cooking.

problem.subgoal: Add the egg and cheese mixture to the pasta without scrambling the eggs.
problem.context: The egg and cheese mixture has been prepared and the pasta has been cooked and removed from boiling water. The pasta water is now simmering.

method.instructions: Turn down the pasta water to a simmer. Add the egg and cheese mixture to the pasta, ensuring the eggs do not scramble. Gently mix so the heat of the pasta cooks the eggs into a creamy sauce.
method.explanations: The eggs cook gently from the heat of the pasta, creating a velvety, creamy sauce without scrambling.
method.supplementary: Be gentle with the pasta to avoid breaking it. The pasta water, bacon fat, and cheese mixture emulsify to create a creamy texture.

result.outcome: The pasta is coated in a creamy, velvety sauce made from the egg and cheese mixture emulsified with pasta water and bacon fat.

problem.subgoal: Adjust the thickness of the pasta sauce.
problem.context: The egg and cheese mixture has been added to the pasta and mixed to create a creamy sauce. The pasta water is simmering on the stove.

method.instructions: If the sauce is too thick, add a little pasta water to loosen it and achieve a creamy consistency. If the sauce is not thick enough, place the pan on top of the simmering pasta water to gently cook the egg mixture further.
method.explanations: Adding pasta water can help loosen the sauce, while placing the pan over simmering water can gently thicken the sauce without scrambling the eggs.
method.supplementary: Using a pan that holds a lot of heat can prevent the need for additional thickening. Adjusting the sauce consistency ensures a creamy texture without scrambling the eggs.

result.outcome: The pasta sauce has the desired creamy consistency without scrambling the eggs.

problem.subgoal: Garnish the pasta with Parmigiano-Reggiano and crispy bacon.
problem.context: The pasta sauce has been adjusted to the desired creamy consistency without scrambling the eggs.

method.instructions: Sprinkle Parmigiano-Reggiano cheese over the pasta. Add crispy bacon on top for added crunch.
method.explanations: Adding Parmigiano-Reggiano enhances the flavor of the pasta, and crispy bacon provides a crunchy texture that complements the creaminess of the sauce.
method.supplementary: Adding crispy bacon is a bonus that adds texture and flavor, and is generally well-received.

result.outcome: The pasta is garnished with cheese and bacon, ready to be served and enjoyed.

common_steps.title: Introduction and ingredient overview
common_steps.text: Pasta. Cream. Bacon. Cream? Hi, guys! We're gonna make spaghetti carbonara, a classic Italian dish pasta. Cheese, bacon. What's not to love, right? But it's really controversial. I want to give you what I think is the most authentic recipe. So first up guys, you only need five ingredients.
common_steps.explanation: This segment introduces the video and gives an overview of the dish and ingredients.

common_steps.title: Introduction and ingredient overview
common_steps.text: So first up guys, you only need five ingredients. Guanciale. This is the cured cheek of pork, and as you can see, it's all about the fat. It's salted, it's got pepper, it's dried, and it's aged. Of course, it's similar to smoked bacon, and you can get some pretty good results, actually, but you can see this is quite lean, so try and get them to not cut off the fat because you need it. Or, there's pancetta. Then most people use parmesan, but actually, the more classic is pecorino romano. Sheep's cheese, it's crumbly, it's salty. Free-range, organic egg, pasta, black pepper, and then, optional, garlic.
common_steps.explanation: This segment continues the introduction by describing the key ingredients needed for the recipe.

common_steps.title: Boil the spaghetti
common_steps.text: So first up guys, grab the pasta by two hands, twist it, into the water. By twisting it, it won't stick together. Put a tiny amount of salt in this water because the cheese and the guanciale is salty. This beautiful pasta takes eight minutes to cook.
common_steps.explanation: The segment describes the process of cooking the spaghetti, which is a necessary step in the recipe.

common_steps.title: Prepare the guanciale
common_steps.text: So I've got my guanciale. I'm gonna remove the skin and I'm gonna take a nice centimeter slice of the guanciale, roughly chop this to about half centimeter chunks. Now, the pan is cold. Turn it on to a medium high heat. The reason I want it cold is because I want to render the fat out. The guanciale goes in to the pan, and this pan is getting hot. Give the garlic a crack, and then put it in the pan. As this starts to sizzle, the fat will just pull out some of that perfume from the garlic.
common_steps.explanation: The segment focuses on preparing and cooking the guanciale, an essential step in making the carbonara.

common_steps.title: Crack and prepare the pepper
common_steps.text: Then there's the black pepper. Get your peppercorns in a pestle and mortar. Crack it. Get a little sieve. This is one of the most important little bits and no one really does it, okay? Honestly. This is the outer skin. This is much milder. What we have here is the inside part of the peppercorn, which is hotter, perfect for a good, hot carbonara.
common_steps.explanation: This segment describes the preparation of the pepper, ensuring the right part is used for a flavorful dish.

common_steps.title: Prepare the egg mixture
common_steps.text: The guanciale is getting golden. Now, let's get on to the eggs. Eggs are really, really delicate, and if you don't treat these right, you end up with stir-fried noodles, and we don't want that. I'm going to take a bowl, and I'm going to crack the egg straight into there, and I'm just going to add a little pecorino to that, to like 20 grams. Now, we're time-sensitive, so we're going to have a little whisk up.
common_steps.explanation: This segment involves preparing the egg mixture with pecorino, which is critical for the carbonara sauce.

common_steps.title: Combine pasta and guanciale
common_steps.text: We've got dark guanciale. You've got the fat that's come out of it, and that's what you want. You want attitude and colors. Now, I'm going to remove that garlic, turn the heat off, and you're going to drag the pasta and the water into the pan. Use the water to stop the frying. A bit fo water! A bit of water! That water and the fat, that's what's gonna emulsify to become a creamy sauce.
common_steps.explanation: This segment describes mixing the cooked spaghetti with the guanciale and its fat, a crucial step before adding the egg mixture.

common_steps.title: Add egg mixture to pasta
common_steps.text: We're not frying anymore, can you hear that? Quiet; no frying at all. Only then, can we think about adding our egg. As we toss, we add some more liquid. Ha-ha! That's the cream. You get the cream through the emulsification of the cooking water, and the fat, and technique, and timing.
common_steps.explanation: This segment explains how to add the egg mixture to the pasta to create a creamy sauce without scrambling the eggs.

common_steps.title: Serve and garnish
common_steps.text: So as simple as this is, it's technical. Get your friends, your family, get them around the table, glass of wine, Look at that, guys, look at that! Carbonara!
common_steps.explanation: This segment involves serving the carbonara, a satisfying conclusion to the cooking process.

common_steps.title: Serve and garnish
common_steps.text: And you finish with more pepper. Wow! I'm so excited. Spaghetti carbonara with a beautiful, little finishing of pecorino. That is as classic as I can give you guys. From chefs, from nonnas, it's about quality ingredients, the guanciale, the pecorino romano, quality eggs, the pepper — the technique of the pepper, a good pasta, and then the sensitivity of cooking it right. Come on. There's a little platter for two people, and of course, the most important thing, when you eat pasta is don't watch it, eat it! Mmmm. That, my friends, is a thing of joy.
common_steps.explanation: The segment continues with serving the carbonara, emphasizing the importance of quality ingredients and proper technique.

method.procedure:
1. Gather five main ingredients: guanciale (or pancetta), pecorino romano cheese, free-range organic egg, pasta, and black pepper. Optionally, use garlic.
2. Twist the pasta and put it in boiling water with a tiny amount of salt. Cook for 8 minutes.
3. Remove the skin from guanciale and chop into half-centimeter chunks.
4. Place guanciale in a cold pan, turn to medium-high heat to render the fat.
5. Crack garlic and add to the pan to infuse flavor, then add cracked black pepper.
6. As guanciale turns golden, crack eggs into a bowl, add pecorino cheese, and whisk.
7. Remove garlic from the pan, turn off heat, and add pasta with water to the pan to stop frying.
8. Add egg mixture to the pan, tossing and adding more pasta water to emulsify into a creamy sauce.
9. Serve with more black pepper and pecorino cheese on top.

result.outcome: The result is a classic and authentic spaghetti carbonara with a creamy texture achieved through emulsification, featuring flavorful guanciale, rich pecorino cheese, and perfectly cooked pasta.

problem.subgoal: Introduction to making spaghetti carbonara.
problem.context: The video has just started, introducing the dish to be made: spaghetti carbonara.

method.supplementary: The narrator emphasizes the authenticity of the recipe and mentions that only five ingredients are needed.

result.outcome: The viewer is introduced to the dish and is informed about the simplicity and authenticity of the recipe.

problem.subgoal: Gather ingredients for a classic pasta dish.
problem.context: Starting the process of preparing a classic pasta dish, presumably Carbonara, which traditionally requires specific ingredients.

method.tools: Guanciale, Pecorino Romano cheese, free-range organic eggs, pasta, black pepper, optional garlic
method.instructions: Gather the following ingredients: guanciale or pancetta, Pecorino Romano cheese, free-range organic eggs, pasta, black pepper, and optionally garlic.
method.explanations: Guanciale is preferred for its fat content which is essential for the dish. Pecorino Romano is the more classic cheese compared to Parmesan. Using quality ingredients like free-range eggs enhances the dish.
method.supplementary: Ensure the guanciale is not overly lean; the fat is important for the dish. Parmesan can be used as a substitute for Pecorino Romano, but it is less traditional.

result.outcome: You will have all the necessary ingredients ready to begin preparing the dish.

problem.subgoal: Cook pasta properly for carbonara.
problem.context: This is the first step in preparing the pasta for the carbonara dish.

method.instructions: Grab the pasta by two hands, twist it, and put it into the water. Add a tiny amount of salt to the water.
method.explanations: Twisting the pasta before putting it in the water helps prevent it from sticking together. Adding a small amount of salt is necessary as the other ingredients (cheese and guanciale) are already salty.

result.outcome: The pasta is cooked properly in salted water, ready in eight minutes.

problem.subgoal: Render the fat from guanciale and infuse with garlic flavor.
problem.context: Prepare guanciale by removing the skin and chopping it into chunks. Ensure the cooking pan is cold before starting.

method.instructions: Remove the skin from the guanciale and slice it into 1 cm slices, then chop into 0.5 cm chunks. Place the guanciale in a cold pan and turn the heat to medium-high. Crack the garlic and add it to the pan.
method.explanations: Starting with a cold pan helps to render the fat from the guanciale slowly, allowing it to infuse with the garlic flavor.
method.supplementary: Ensure the pan is cold before adding guanciale to properly render the fat.

result.outcome: The fat from the guanciale is rendered out, and the garlic infuses its flavor into the fat.

problem.subgoal: Prepare black pepper for hot carbonara.
problem.context: The previous steps are not provided, but this is part of preparing ingredients for a dish, likely carbonara.

method.instructions: Place peppercorns in a pestle and mortar and crack them. Then, use a sieve to separate the outer skin from the inner part of the peppercorns.
method.explanations: The outer skin of the peppercorn is milder, while the inner part is hotter, which is better for making a good, hot carbonara.
method.supplementary: This step is important and often overlooked, as most people do not separate the peppercorns this way.

result.outcome: You have separated the milder outer skin from the hotter inner part of the peppercorns, ready for use in a hot carbonara dish.

problem.subgoal: Prepare egg and pecorino mixture for carbonara.
problem.context: The guanciale is being cooked until golden, and the pepper has been prepared by cracking and separating it.

method.instructions: Crack an egg into a bowl and add about 20 grams of pecorino cheese. Whisk the mixture quickly.
method.explanations: Eggs are delicate and need to be whisked carefully to avoid them turning into a scrambled consistency when mixed with hot pasta.
method.supplementary: It is important to whisk the mixture quickly due to time sensitivity.

result.outcome: A whisked mixture of egg and pecorino is prepared, ready to be added to the pasta for carbonara.

problem.subgoal: Combine pasta with rendered guanciale fat to create a creamy sauce.
problem.context: The pasta has been boiled and the guanciale has been cooked to render its fat and infuse it with garlic flavor.

method.instructions: Remove the garlic from the pan with the rendered guanciale fat. Turn off the heat. Drag the pasta and some pasta water into the pan with the guanciale fat. Use the water to stop the frying and emulsify the sauce.
method.explanations: The starch in the pasta water helps emulsify the fat from the guanciale to create a creamy sauce.
method.supplementary: Use only a little bit of pasta water to stop the frying and create the sauce.

result.outcome: The pasta is combined with the rendered guanciale fat and pasta water, forming a creamy sauce.

problem.subgoal: Add the egg mixture to the pasta and guanciale.
problem.context: The pasta has been combined with the rendered guanciale fat and pasta water to form a creamy sauce, and the frying has stopped.

method.instructions: Add the egg mixture to the pasta once the frying sound stops, indicating the right time to incorporate the eggs.
method.explanations: The absence of frying sound indicates the right temperature where the eggs can be added without scrambling, allowing them to emulsify with the sauce.
method.supplementary: Timing is crucial to prevent the eggs from scrambling and to achieve the creamy texture of the sauce.

result.outcome: The egg mixture is added to the pasta, contributing to a creamy carbonara sauce.

problem.subgoal: Present the prepared Carbonara dish to friends or family.
problem.context: The Carbonara dish has already been prepared and is ready to be served.

method.instructions: Gather your friends or family around the table to present the Carbonara dish.
method.explanations: Sharing a meal with loved ones is a social and enjoyable experience, enhancing the meal's appeal and enjoyment.
method.supplementary: Consider serving with a glass of wine to enhance the dining experience.

result.outcome: The Carbonara dish is shared and enjoyed with friends or family.

problem.subgoal: Finish spaghetti carbonara with pepper and pecorino.
problem.context: The spaghetti carbonara has been prepared and is ready for final touches.

method.instructions: Add more pepper and a finishing of pecorino cheese to the spaghetti carbonara.
method.explanations: The finishing touches of pepper and pecorino add flavor and authenticity to the dish, highlighting the importance of quality ingredients and proper technique.
method.supplementary: Quality ingredients such as guanciale, pecorino romano, quality eggs, and good pasta are essential for a classic carbonara. The sensitivity of cooking it right is crucial.

result.outcome: The spaghetti carbonara is completed with a finishing of pepper and pecorino, ready to be served and enjoyed.
